Connecticut prides itself on being green. It claims to have been the first state to open a recycling center. The state has proposed spending millions more to clean up Long Island Sound.
But when it comes to noise pollution, and giving residents some relief from the roar of the highways, Connecticut has given the same answer for more than 15 years: it's not a priority.
Try telling that to the thousands of people living next to the ever-more-congested Interstates 95 and 91, where the sound of motorcycles speeding up and 18-wheelers downshifting is a constant din.

In a positive move, the legislature's Joint Committee on Transportation has approved a bill that would authorize a study on where sound barriers are needed the most. The money would enable the Department of Transportation to measure the sound levels in different areas and draw up a priority list, based on noise, of where the walls should go. That is the fairest way to proceed.

Building the walls does not come cheap. The cost is more than $1 million a mile. But the state has done next to nothing on this issue since 1990. That is when Gov. Lowell Weicker, faced with a huge budget deficit, canceled the program.

Since then, only those who lived near a highway that was undergoing expansion could qualify for the wooden structures, which are often 15 feet high. In those instances, the state has used federal money to construct the walls.
When the program ended, there were 131 areas on a waiting list. After a hiatus of 17 years, no doubt even more areas will clamor for help. The initiative is overdue.
